Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:

The obtained samples were characterized by the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) method and the XRD data were analyzed by the Rietveld refinement method. The results illustrate that all the phases can be indexed to scheelite structure. Luminescence spectroscopy was carried out and decay curves as well as time-resolved photoluminescence spectra measured at room temperature were obtained. Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
As the so-called next-generation solid-state illuminant lighting develops, light-emitting diodes (LEDs) have drawn much attention in recent years due to their wide applications in solid-state lighting [1â€“4]. LEDs exhibit several superior advantages when compared to conventional light sources, such as higher luminous efficiency, lower power consumption, longer survival life and more environmentally friendliness [5]. Therefore, LEDs are considered as clean light sources and environmentally friendly equipment in view of the increasing demands for saving power consumption in our daily life. Up to now, there are several ways to obtain white light. One of the well-known commercial ways to generate white light in present years is to combine a GaN blue chip with a
Ce
3 +
$\mathrm{Ce}^{3+}$ -doped yttrium aluminum garnet (
YAG:Ce
3 +
$\mbox{YAG:Ce}^{3+}$ ) yellow-emitting phosphor [6]. However, the problems of low color rendering index (CRI), high color temperature and narrow visible range block the extensive applications of the white LEDs because they lack the red emission phosphors [7]. What is more, another way to gain white light can be ascribed to the use of red, green and blue LED chips, but the color temperature will change significantly with the increase of the temperature, leading to the restriction of its usable range. However, with the development of the study of the red phosphors and the LED chips, now there is a third method to obtain white LEDs, namely, combining UV/near-UV LED chips with red, green and blue (RGB) tricolor phosphors [8]. Unfortunately, the present commercial red phosphors, such as

What is more, in order to obtain an ideal color rendering, the amount of red phosphor to obtain white light is about eight times more than that of blue and green phosphors. Therefore, it is necessary to explore efficient and stable red phosphors.

Calcium tungstate (CaWO4) is widely used as an X-ray phosphor, scintillating material and laser host medium for its superior luminescent and chemical properties [2, 3, 5]. Moreover, some new luminescence properties can be found by doping with transition-metal ions or rare-earth ions. In addition, the red afterglow properties of
